body:
IIRC `HEAD` requests are not supposed to have a BODY.

It looks like `OPTIONS` is supported, no?

I would need to investigate if there is anything interesting for `DELETED` and why it wasn't supported. @fredericBregier - any thoughts, here is the last commit to touch this section of code https://github.com/netty/netty/commit/651c7b056a386254165303a23fc9d4d917477ffb#diff-6c2ed3f1910d6227cdb16bd578244c5dR192

DELETE could be supported too since it is allowed, even if there is a big warn on the RFC that most of the implementations could not support this.

Currently in my project, we do use BODY with POST, PUT, PATCH, DELETE but also with **GET**.

Only HEAD is not allowed to have a body in request part (RFC 7231). So we might allow any methods except HEAD.

body:
@Scottmitch for most of REST application, where a single request through uri parameter is not enough, a body is mandatory. It is not refused, contrary to HEAD, as noticed: "might cause some existing implementations to reject the request". 

It is not standard and not fully supported, I agree, but even the RFC said that it could be useful. And as I note (my current project use this), in REST interface, GET or DELETE could use it. Of course, it is not mandatory, but preventing it might lead to implement this without Netty.

So yes, we might write a disclaimer, letting the final implementation (business code) to implement or not those methods with body. I'm recalling the old proposal (closed 6 month ago now since no activity on it) about adding support for REST support natively in Netty. It might be one way to allow/disallow by knowing it those extra support. One way to do it could be to have as in Apache Http Client / Jersey a special configuration that said "Allow Non official" (ClientProperties.SUPPRESS_HTTP_COMPLIANCE_VALIDATION).

WDYT?

AFAIK, the first app to make heavy use of request bodies with all HTTP methods, even GET, was ElasticSearch. So GET requests with a body is definitely something very common nowadays.

And then, there's the case of custom HTTP methods, e.g. WebDav, Varnish's PURGE and whatever people might come up with.

I originally had this kind of restrictions in AHC where I would only allow some methods to have a body. This caused tons of limitations, and I finally lifted them and allow body of all methods by HEAD.
I'm not against it and we generally don't impose limitations on these methods it in the core of Netty, so adding a disclaimer with a link to the RFC sgtm.
+1 too. Who is taking this one?

Hey, I was sure you're going to tell that... ;-) I will try (holiday time but some time however)

So allowing all except HEAD with a link to the RFC with warning on usage is enough ?

Just for 100% sure, reading the RFC 7231, it seems only the following is not allowed to have a body:

- TRACE : "A client MUST NOT send a message body in a TRACE request." (4.3.8)

while others are either explicitely allowed:
- POST
- PUT
- OPTIONS

Or with the following warning: where you can replace XXX by GET, HEAD, DELETE, CONNECT
"A payload within a XXX request message has no defined semantics;
   sending a payload body on a XXX request might cause some existing
   implementations to reject the request."

I was wrong saying that HEAD is not allowed (probably too fast reading).

So I'm proposing to allow all except TRACE, and adding a special warning in the Decoder class with reference to the sentence of the RFC above. Is that ok ?

issue.title: Extends HttpPostRequestEncoder to support all methods except TRACE

repository.name: netty
repository.description: Netty project - an event-driven asynchronous network application framework

issue.body:
Motivation:

In Netty, currently, the HttpPostRequestEncoder only supports POST, PUT, PATCH and OPTIONS, while the RFC 7231 allows with a warning that GET, HEAD, DELETE and CONNECT use a body too (but not TRACE where it is explicitely not allowed).
The RFC in chapter 4.3 says:
"A payload within a XXX request message has no defined semantics;
sending a payload body on a XXX request might cause some existing
implementations to reject the request."
where XXX can be replaced by one of GET, HEAD, DELETE or CONNECT.

Current usages, on particular in REST mode, tend to use those extra HttpMethods for such queries.

So this PR proposes to remove the current restrictions, leaving only TRACE as explicitely not supported.

Modification:

In the constructor, where the test is done, replacing all by checking only against TRACE, and adding one test to check that all methods are supported or not.

Result:

Fixes #6138.
